Award.AwardTitle: Tests of Fundamental Symmetries with Atoms and Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
A novel class of ultra-precise atomic clocks based on highly-charged ions will be developed. Such clocks hold an intriguing promise of extending the frontiers of precision measurements. Atomic clocks have both practical (navigation, geodesy, and network synchronization) and fundamental applications. Additionally, advanced tools of computational atomic physics will be used to establish powerful constraints on postulated, but so-far undiscovered exotic interactions related to dark matter and dark forces. Such constraints are unique and at the same time complementary to those derived from particle colliders, such as LHC.

The research will be carried out in Nevada, one of the EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) states, underrepresented in the scientific enterprize. This fulfills one of the strategic goals of the NSF to 'broaden participation and enhance diversity in NSF programs'; research and education of a graduate student partially supported with the goal of 'advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning'. The findings will be disseminated through publications in scientific journals, conference presentations, and the Internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

We carried out theoretical research aimed at basic understanding of exotic interactions in atomic physics and improving accuracy of precision measurement devices. These topics naturally fit into the broad context of precision measurements, a longtime and exceptionally fruitful atomic physics tradition. As a result, we further developed a novel class of atomic clocks based on highly-charged ions. This work paves the road towards reaching the next precision frontier in modern timekeeping which is anticipated to be of relevance to metrology, fundamental physics, and various time-keeping applications. 

Perhaps the most significant outcome is our developed idea to leverage the precision of atomic clocks to search for dark matter. While multiple astrophysical observations indicate that 85% of the matter in the Universe is composed of dark matter, its microscopic nature remains a mystery. Dark matter signals remain elusive in laboratories. We pointed out that networks of atomic clocks, such as clocks onboard Global Positioning System satellites, can be uniquely sensitive to dark-matter induced transient variations of fundamental constants. Dark matter signals would exhibit a characteristic signature in experimental data. Our proposal indicated the intriguing possibility and analyzed the discovery reach of dark matter searches with atomic clocks.

 

Broader impacts

The research was carried out in Nevada, one of the EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) states, underrepresented in the scientific enterprise. The funding fulfilled one of the strategic goals of the NSF to broaden participation and enhance diversity in NSF programs. This grant partially supported research and education of five undergraduate students with the goal of advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning. While the funding was inadequate for supporting graduate students, graduate students associated with the research group benefited from computational server partially supported by this grant. Two students graduated with Ph.D. degrees; both moved to postdoctoral positions at other institutions.

The findings were disseminated through publications in scientific journals, conference presentations, and the Internet. Some of the findings were covered by popular media, educating general public.
